title: Is it legal to use purchased iTunes music for other purposes (background music for personal video clips, for example). Does the copyright law allow? - Quora

response.answer_text: Technically, you don't purchase music from iTunes, you purchase a license for the music. The license permits you obtain a digital copy of the music and play it back on devices connected to your iTunes account. You aren't licensed to make derivative works of the music, redistribute the music, incorporate them into movie clips, etc. To do so would be infringing and carry the associated penalties (statutory $150,000 fine, damages, possible jail time). That said, there are two other considerations: first is that truly personal uses are not likely to result in an infringement claim if there's no redistribution because the cost of prosecution is not worth it; second is that US law allows an accused infringer to assert fair use under some specific circumstances: the work was used in a situation where it was the subject of critical review or comment, it was used in part or in summary in a news report, it was used for a non-profit educational use, or it is used in a parody (a work that  satirizes or ridicules another). A court will determine whether a particular use seems like a "fair use" to the court (and sometimes they will accept certain uses that aren't specifically cited in the law). Generally speaking, you should restrict yourself to using music that is permissively licensed (Creative Commons or public-domain) wherever possible. Otherwise, license the music from the label properly for reuse.

You are not buying the music, but very specific rights to use the music, which may vary by juridstiction.  Generally, the rights are for personal and noncommerical use.  You cannot publicly perform this music, include it in your own works, transmit over a radio to an audience, or anything like that. In the United States:http://www.apple.com/legal/internet-services/itunes/us/terms.html USAGE RULES(i) You shall be authorized to use iTunes Products only for personal, noncommercial use.(ii)  You shall be authorized to use iTunes Products on five  iTunes-authorized devices at any time, except for Content Rentals (see  below). (iii) You shall be able to store iTunes Products from up  to five different Accounts at a time on compatible devices, provided  that each iPhone may sync tone iTunes Products with only a single  iTunes-authorized device at a time, and syncing an iPhone with a  different iTunes-authorized device will cause tone iTunes Products  stored on that iPhone to be erased.(iv) You shall be authorized to burn an audio playlist up to seven times.(v) You shall not be entitled to burn video iTunes Products or tone iTunes Products.(vi)  iTunes Plus Products do not contain security technology that limits  your usage of such products, and Usage Rules (ii) – (v) do not apply to  iTunes Plus Products. You may copy, store, and burn iTunes Plus Products  as reasonably necessary for personal, noncommercial use. There's more, but this is the crux of it. Disclaimer: I am not a lawyer.
